About the light - I think best way would be just one flash (sometimes less is more), and the same exposure setting (fixed) on all the cameras - I think It would feel more realistic as in real life there typically is only one strong source of light, darker images in some angles would not be problem as the transition from the brighter ones would be gradual - and it would feel really like one camera moving through space independent of time. Norway is a democracy and it's been here for 199 years...
And if you say "well America is democracy and it's been here for 237 years" your wrong because America is a republic and you can google the difference.

Democracy has a few fundamental flaws which end up causing them to collapse very quickly. Usually by the head official not giving up power after their term in office is up. Historically no democracy has stayed a democracy longer than a few years before falling into a more tyrannical form of government. The other big one is mob rule "the public" does not have the ability to make important decisions.
Look, There is a certain risk in democracy. No one's denying that, but it's a risk that's worth it. obviously over half the population of (most) of the major civilizations in the world agree with me.

I don't know many people who feel that slavery is OK these days... HOWEVER, it did exist at some point in our past, and the majority of people were "ok" with it or endorced it.

I'm just saying, in a democracy there is room for things like that to happen.

Then it sucks to be the other 49 % And yes I would probably change my mind right quick if anything like that ever happened. Here in Norway we are however taught ethics at a little something called a school, and absolutely everyone goes to the schools. Which means that just about everyone (it's not perfect.) will if nothing else despise slavery. It's a bad system even if you put away the ethics for a minute anyway, because slaves can rebel.

"I'm happy with things as they are."
REALLY?! Do you live in the US?
I don't know you from a box of rocks, so I will have to be hypothetical here...
Let's say you LOVE fishing. I mean LOVE it.
Now let's say that 51% of the (democratic) country you live-in felt that fishing was "animal cruelty". Because the majority (51%) rules in a democracy, fishing is made illegal. How would you feel?
What if you were a black person living in the 1800s and the majority endorced slavery?

I don't think republic qualifies as "You should be the one to decide what's best for you and only you." to paraphrase what you said earlier, every form of government ever has left some people unhappy, to varying degrees. A democracy is designed to make the most people possible happy, now I don't know what a republic is really supposed to be like and I don't really care, I'm happy with things as they are.

I don't advocate anarchy. There is a form of government called a "Republic". Perhaps you've heard of it. It's what our country is supposed to be. Watch this video, it does a good job explaining the differences.
watch?v=KFXuGIpsdE0&list=FLuBhaZB9B0y5SNT1q-NPxjw&index=14

Hopefully it will help you to understand why democracy is not great.

Also if everyone was to decide for themselves what was best we would have what's commonly referred to as a anarchy, which would mean a total infrastructure collapse in very little time and soon after we would be back in the stone ages. there's a reason why governments have evolved to be the way they are. (then again there is also a reason why empires and kingdoms tend to last so long, because they work.)
I'm thinking the enormous bank might have something to do with the 33% tax rate and the oil wells.

Fiscal responsibility is only part of the equation my friend. I admit, I know very little about Norway, it's encouraging to know that somehow their mentality has allowed them keep restraint when they know that they could easily put that 3 trillion in their pockets.

Like I said though, fiscal issues are only part of the equation. In a democracy, the majority gets to decide what's best for you, not yourself. That's not right on a fundamental level. Think about it.

Fiscal responsibility is only part of the equation my friend. I admit, I know very little about Norway, it's encouraging to know that somehow their mentality has allowed them keep restraint when they know that they could easily put that 3 trillion in their pockets.

Like I said though, fiscal issues are only part of the equation. In a democracy, the majority gets to decide what's best for you, not yourself. That's not right on a fundamental level. Think about it.
On the other hand you can look over at Norway and see a democratic country with 3 trillion (krones not dollars) in it's bank.

You're making the mistake of assuming that you have to have democracy in-order to have freedom of speech.
That is not true.

And what if 51% of the people wished to own slaves?
Just because the majority of people get their way, DOES NOT make it ok. The moment the majority begins to take-away my natural rights, then democracy has failed.
You cannot seriously sit there, looking at a 16 TRILLION+ dollar defecit and claim democracy is a success. The government spends WAY too much $ pure and simple. When we the people continue to vote ourselves the riches of the public treasury, how can we ever succeed?

"Learn some history." The most overused comment by people trying to sound smart and belittle others. I'm sad that I used to use that comment.
I have an idea, why don't you explore some of the democracies of the past. Compare how many have endured and how many have failed. Let me know of your findings.
Every democracy I can think-of which has existed for more than 100 years is in great debt. They cannot continue that path indefinately. Therefore Tyler's quote DOES hold water.

Democracys with constitution don't end up to a dictatorship. That's wrong. Learn 
some history. Not every democracy has to end up like that. And that is because most people are rational.

If you think democracy is the reason that US is in debt because of democracy, and democracy means mob rule, then I'm really disappointed people think things like that. Also, democracy means that if this is your opinion, then you can say it freely and vote for it. You and the rest of the people have the power. Democracy leaves most people satisfied. Calling democracy mob rule is wrong. It's like calling youreself mob. This is just my belief, and in democracy all beliefs must be respected.

Democracy is NOT mob rule. Democracy DOES equal freedom. If 51% of US citizens decided that they want to make guns illegal and they did, then that 51% would be satisfied. But if it wasn't democracy, and guns remained legal, then 49% would be satisfied. That's not good. The point is to satisfy as many people as you can. If you are the minority and don't want democracy because you weren't satisfied, then you are selfish. Democracy has constitution, because most people have a good judgement.

I too want to be able to own and use guns for personal defense. The problem with a democracy is this; If 51% of the US citizens decided that they wanted to make guns illegal because they are "too dangerous" then they could. The problem with a democracy is that your right to defend yourself can be simply voted-away if the majority of the US decides to do so. Democracy does not equal freedom. It equals mob-rule. You want rights that can't be simply voted-away? You want a republic. :)

Ah now I see your point but no I'd rather live in a country that's bound to fail if I can choose what the hell to do. I think you kinda missed the point of my quote. We don't want a democracy. Democracies are bad. They are bound to fail. The US was originally a Republic. It has somehow morphed into a failing Democracy. Democracy means mob rule. It means people simply voting themselves whatever they want, at the expense of the public treasury. Pretty soon there is nothing left (pretty soon you end up Trillions of $ in-debt just like the US is now). Democracy is not the answer.
